results.notes:
Growing on the underside of dead Ostrya virginiana leaf among wet hardwood leaf litter. Apothecia very light gray and sessile. Ascocarp width measurements: (141.8) 146.2 – 302.2 (306.5) µm; N = 12; Me = 219.4 µm. Hairs absent. Ectal excipulum of textura angularis with hyaline elements. Paraphyses hyaline and clavate. Asci inoperculate, unitunicate, 8-spored and with amyloid apical pores. Ascus measurements: (48.9) 54.4 – 67 (71.7) × (7) 8.1 – 9.7 (10.2) µm; Q = (5.5) 5.8 – 7.7 (8.4); N = 30; Me = 59.8 × 8.9 µm; Qe = 6.7. Spores hyaline, filiform, smooth, thin-walled and up to 3-septate. Spore measurements: (36.3) 38.5 – 46.8 (51.1) × (1.5) 1.6 – 2.2 (2.4) µm; Q = (16.8) 19.3 – 24.7 (31.4); N = 30; Me = 42.3 × 1.9 µm; Qe = 22.3

—

results.notes:
Growing abundantly in mulch along the side of a road near Pinus strobus, Pinus sp., Thuja occidentalis, Picea sp., Abies balsamea and Acer sp. Some basidiocarps caespitose. Caps hygrophanous with gelatinous pellicles and translucent-striate margins; 5.6 to 21.5 mm wide and 1.9 to 5.7 mm tall. Gills adnexed. Stems 13.4 to 23.5 mm long and 1.1 to 3.7 mm wide. Basal mycelium white. All surfaces bruising strongly blue. Odor not distinctive. Taste slightly nutty. Spore print purple-brown. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia forming a sterile margin. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores smooth. Spore measurements: (6.7) 7.1 – 8.5 (9.7) × (3.7) 3.9 – 4.7 (5.1) µm; Q = (1.7) 1.71 – 2 (2.1); N = 30; Me = 7.9 × 4.3 µm; Qe = 1.9

—

results.notes:
Collected along the Paul Smith’s College VIC Boreal Life Trail. Growing on Abies balsamea twigs among leaf litter near Fagus grandifolia, Picea sp., Acer spp. and Viburnum sp. Caps glutinous; 4.3 to 14.4 mm wide and 2.8 to 5.9 mm tall. Cortina-like veil present. Gills adnate to sinuate. Basal mycelium copious and white. Stems 16.1 to 44.8 mm long and 1.0 to 1.7 mm wide Annulus absent. All surfaces bruising blue. Odor not distinctive. Taste slightly bitter and sour. Pleurocystidia absent or scarce. Cheilocystidia hyaline and forming a sterile margin. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores brown, thick-walled and with germ pores. Spore measurements: (6.8) 6.9 – 8.8 (9.8) × (3.8) 4.3 – 4.9 (5) µm; Q = (1.5) 1.6 – 1.9 (2); N = 30; Me = 8 × 4.6 µm; Qe = 1.7

—

results.notes:
Growing singly in needle litter near Abies balsamea, Fagus grandifolia, Betula allegheniensis, Picea sp. and Acer spp. Cap dry and finely strigose; pinkish buff; 24.7 mm wide and 6.2 mm tall. Stem smooth, dry and apically pruinose. Basal mycelium white. Cap and stem context white. Odor not distinctive. Taste farinose. All structures inamyloid. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 1-sterigmate to 4-sterigmate. Spores spiny, thick-walled and yellowish-brown in Melzer’s reagent. Spore measurements: (3.4) 3.8 – 4.5 (5.3) × (2.8) 3 – 3.9 (4.3) µm; Q = 1.1 – 1.3 (1.4); N = 30; Me = 4.2 × 3.5 µm; Qe = 1.2

results.notes:
I’m not familiar with how to measure and evaluate a fungus like this, but I measured things and will do my best.

Collector: Lauren Re

With synnemata, branching or unbranching, emerging first as hyaline to blueish triangulate, spear shaped projections. Growing about to the size of a matured globose stalked asexual structure, then differentiating into the asexual structures with simple chains of conidia.

Widths of synnemata and whether or not they were producing conidia yet.
27.07um – Vesicle clearly visible – phialade structure becoming recognizeable – no conidia, faintly blue green throughout stalk, becoming hyaline towards vesicle.
39.26um – Blue green in stalk and vesicle, becoming hyaline towards immature conidia not yet formed formed now.
56.39um – Black to blue black stalk, vesicle solidly pigmented blue green, with hyaline hyphae looking structures with abundant conidia – chains not observed- when fully mature.

125um – Dark black stalk, dark blue vesicle with fully mature chains of conidia, Larger and more globose asexual blob of conidial chains.

Elliptical Hyaline spores, containing no oil droplets that I could find.

Spores in H20

(3.1) 3.3 – 4 (4.2) × (1.5) 1.7 – 2 (2.2) µm
Q = (1.7) 1.72 – 2.2 (2.3) ; N = 17
Me = 3.6 × 1.9 µm ; Qe = 2

Spores in KOH

(2.9) 3.1 – 3.5 (3.6) × (1.4) 1.5 – 1.9 µm
Q = 1.7 – 2.2 (2.4) ; N = 18
Me = 3.3 × 1.7 µm ; Qe = 1.9

results.notes:
Growing on Ammophila sp. – Dune grass. After talking with some botanists, the dune grass along the coasts was spread intentionally to attempt to stabilize the dunes- I wonder if this species is native to the pacific coast, or rather hitched a ride with the grass.

Ecological observation- It interests me that this genera is more typically tropica, as is Tetrapyrgos, Marasmiellus (though this is widely dispersed), and Calyptella. This is of course anectdotal.

Very small, photos with penny for scale.
Possible Sp. nov, or underdescribed species.
Worked through the monograph of Favolaschia by Rolf Singer – Landed in sect. Depauperatae- Then to “Species incompletely known”

I landed on Favolaschia phillipinensis, but was unable to find anything more on that species.
Then there was Favolaschia fujijanensis, which is small and white and inhabits bamboo, a fellow Poaceae, perhaps this sp. is in a similar lineage of the genera.

I am aware this sect. may have been broken up by now, by the distribution of gloeocystidia and pigments. Not sure how to assess such, haven’t spend the time or asked the right people in order to find out.

Gloeocystidia and vessels present – Cystidia of at least two types, globular club shaped cystidia with warts and long club shaped cystidia with spiny projections (dendrohyphidia?)

Spore Measurements: subglobose to elliptical with droplet. Apicular plug present.

results.notes:
On redwood driftwood. 9.11.21: Thallus pale yellow, continuous, occasionally breaking into yellow soredia, often in cracks of wood, soralia 0.1-0.3mm approx and usually rounded. Thallus and maybe more often soredia C+O strong. Apothecia originating somewhat immersed, with a raised pale scurfy rim and concave pruinose disk. Becoming flexuous, with reduced rim, partly convex with central concave area. This specimen has disk parasitized by something creating light brown flecks. Epihymenium golden to reddish, with sparse golden crystals, hymenium hyaline, short, hypothecium very deep. Amphithecium with a thin cortex, not thickened at base, strongly POL+ white crystals extending into the subhymenium.
Spores simple, hyaline, ellipsoid, about 11×5µm.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1412/2021_4602

Habitat: River bank, light mixed forest, at the base of a steep mountain, northeast aspect, locally almost flat terrain, calcareous ground, partly in shade, relatively cold and humid air place, exposed to direct rain, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 6-8 deg C, elevations 525 m (1.720 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: a medium size calcareous, moss overgrown boulder.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, left bank of river Soča, next to Soča trail, near Trenta 46 farmhouse, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Dog lichens (genus Peltigera sp.) are large folios lichens, which often form extensive patches on ground, rocks or grassland. They grow mostly in woods but one can find them also on open places. Particularly the green ones are beautiful when moist and richly developed. To recognize them on genus level is not at all a problem. However, to determine them correctly (particularly gray-brown ones) on species level is sometimes quite a challenge, more so, if the thali are sterile that is without apothecia. The large difference in their appearance between being in dry or moist state are often striking. So, wrong determinations are quite common. Peltigera canina is a species, which is frequently confused with others, most often with very similar (and much more frequent) Peltigera membranacea. Peltigera canina can be distinguished from other species by irregular, shaggy, markedly bushy, confluent at the base, white rhizines and fuzzy tomentum on the upper side of the lobes. The underside has flattened, smooth and whitish veins (except sometimes in the middle of the thallus where they may be darker). Quite rare, roundish and very dark brown to black apothecia are also typical. Richly branched, woolly rhizines are most diagnostic (Ref.:1.) (see Fig.3a.). However, this rhizines form is not the only one present. Often several other shapes, including those common to Peltigera membranacea, are present or even dominant. Yet, no other Peltigera species has rhizines of this typical appearance than Peltigera canina.

The lichen was one time used to treat rabies because the rhizines supposedly look like dogs’ teeth (Ref.:4.).

Ref.:
(1) C.W.Smith, et all, The lichens of Great Britain and Ireland,The British Lichen
Society (2009), p 667.
(2) I.M. Brodo, S.D. Sharnoff, S.Sharnoff, Lichens of North America, Yale Uni. Press (2001), p 506.
(3) V. Wirth, Die Flechten Baden-Württembergs, Teil. 2., Ulmer (1995), p 681.
(4) F.S. Dobson, Lichens, The Richmonds Publishing Ca.LTD (2005), p 325.

Camera: Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70 mm/f4

results.notes:
Fruiting in grass beneath Douglas fir.

Cap: pinkish gray/brown, fibrillose. Young specimens with Vibrant cottony lilac banded/girdled margin. NOT SILKY.
Caps have tendency to crack radially/concentrically (starting near disc-outward).
Stem: whitish lilac, slightly striated.

Spores: distinctly almond shaped, thick walled, smooth.
Profile Spores(side laying): inequilateral(banana shaped). See images included of my work here.

Harvested /dehydrated 7 specimens for herbarium collection/voucher.

results.notes:
On bare ground with scattered needles, under planted Norway spruce. Mostly in small clusters.
Cap surface smooth/shiny with innate radial fibrils; brownish.
Gills attached via broad/deep notch.
Spores smooth (or nearly so), ellipsoid 7.5-9 × 4-5. Not dextrinoid. Print yellowish light brown (not a thick print).
Pleurocystidia not found.
Cheilocystidia thin-walled, mostly with long necks, some slightly flexuous, variably shaped inflated bases, rounded apices.
Bean/potato-shaped cells on/near gill edges.
Lack of (prominent) pleurocystidia eliminates Inocybe. Smooth non-splitting cap surface points away from any of Mallocybe, Inosperma, Pseudosperma.
Apparent lack of pleurocystidia renders Pholiota doubtful.
These are likely old fruit bodies, having remained in-situ during cold weather.

results.notes: Collected this solitary Amanita growing from a mowed lawn beneath a large pin oak adjacent to a parking lot. Very large intact volva, smooth cap with large fragment of veil attached but no warts evident. KOH on cap surface was negative. Most notable characteristic is the foul odor that is reminiscent of musty mildewed books or musty laundry. I replanted the specimen and followed the growth for two days after the initial discovery but cold weather seemed to inhibit further maturation. The stem lengthened a bit but the cap never opened up. Would appreciate help with further identification if possible.

results.notes:
Growing singly in soil on the bank of Greenbrier Road near Carpinus carolinaiana, Quercus sect. Lobatae, Tilia americana, Liriodendron tulipifera, Magnolia acuminata, Rhododendron sp. and Acer sp. Cap conic; 3.3 mm wide and 2.4 mm tall. Gills short-decurrent. Stem smooth; 19.3 mm long and 0.8 mm wide. Strong mothball odor. Clamps absent. Pileipellis a hymeniderm composed mostly of sphaeropedunculate elements. Pileipellis element measurements: (16.3) 19.7 – 35.6 (42.5) × (6.6) 7.6 – 11.2 (12) µm; Q = (1.6) 2.2 – 3.5 (6.4); N = 30; Me = 26.6 × 9.3 µm; Qe = 2.9. Caulocystidia with brown intracellular pigment and often arranged in fascicles. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores hyaline and smooth. Spore measurements: (4.7) 4.9 – 5.8 (6.3) × (3.6) 3.7 – 4.4 (4.8) µm; Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.4 (1.5); N = 30; Me = 5.4 × 4 µm; Qe = 1.3

results.notes: I found this mushroom December 8th 2021. The weather for past week was in low 30’s/high 20’s at night and low 40’s during the day. Have lived in this area for 70+ years and have never seen a mushroom like this here. Our ground is high alkaline but grows lots of meadow mushrooms in the spring and fall when the weather cooperates. The land nearby has rabbit brush, sage brush, crested wheat and native grasses. I would really like to know what this mushroom is. It had a smell similar to the meadow mushrooms but a little bitter.

results.notes:
On pine. Dull pileus surface with a laccate margin. Cuticle rigid, hard. Cuticle cell structure generally difficult to distinguish/fused together in non laccate areas, perhaps more regular and clearly separated in young lacquer at margin. Likewise amyloidity weak in dull cuticle, possibly stronger in laccate portions. Spores diverse but generally large with truncated apex

results.notes:
Growing singly on bare soil at the edge of a trail. Fagus grandifolia, Quercus spp., Aesculus sp., Liriodendron tulipifera, Asimina triloba, Cercis canadensis and a dead Juniperus virginiana present nearby. Cap 0.8 cm. Stem 2.0 cm long and 0.2 cm wide at the widest. Strong mothball odor. Spore print white. Clamps absent. Pileipellis a hymeniderm with obovoid, clavate, or rarelysphaeropenduculate elements. Pileipellis element measurements: 14.6 – 26 (26.1) × (8.4) 9.5 – 15.3 (15.9) µm; Q = 1.1 – 2.47 (2.5); N = 14; Me = 20.2 × 12.1 µm; Qe = 1.7. Caulocystidia sphaeropedunculate, clavate, obovoid, cylindrical, flexuouse or fusoid with obtuse apices; often in fascicles; hyaline or with brown intracellular pigments. Caulocystidia measurements: (12.1) 15.1 – 32.7 (47.9) × (5.2) 6.1 – 10.6 (13.6) µm; Q = (1.3) 1.6 – 4.9 (5.3); N = 30; Me = 24.3 × 8.5 µm; Qe = 3. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia clavate and 4-sterigmate. Spores hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (4.3) 4.6 – 6.9 (7.4) × (3.4) 3.9 – 4.9 (6.1) µm; Q = (1) 1.2 – 1.6 (1.7); N = 30; Me = 5.7 × 4.2 µm; Qe = 1.4

—

results.notes: Nine specimens, a representative one featured, were found near the bottom of a slope in an area where they have been seen in past years, most recently in 2016. Fruiting bodies were found in an area about 25 feet diameter; only one other was found anywhere close by. The 9 specimens were growing in leaf litter under live oaks with a couple gray pines in the area as well. If not for a couple of large specimens past prime, might have missed altogether due to camouflage in brown leaf litter. Pileus was dark brown with some lighter brown patches. Tubes were light creamy yellow getting more dingy/green in past-prime specimens. Stipes were solid white. Reticulation was present at top of stipe, but only visible with close observation. Did not see whitish bloom often reported for this putative queen bolete.

Trees present in the general area were Fagus grandifolia, Quercus sect, Lobatae, Quercus alba, Carya spp., Pinus echinata, Pinus rigida, Carpinus caroliniana, Ostrya virginiana, Tilia americana, Sassafras albidum, Oxydendron arboreum, Kalmia latifolia, Liriodendron tulipiferum, Acer saccharum and other hardwoods. Caps dry with rimose margins. Stems pruinose over their entire lengths, tinged reddish with rimmed bulbous bases. Pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia metuloids. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores nodulose and brown. Spore measurements: (6) 7.1 – 9.2 (10.6) × (4.4) 5.1 – 6.7 (7.9) µm; Q = (1.2) 1.22 – 1.5 (1.6); N = 30; Me = 8 × 5.9 µm; Qe = 1.4

—

results.notes:

Spores smooth and pale brown in Melzer’s. Spore measurements: (7) 7.8 – 9.6 (10.3) × (4.7) 5 – 5.7 (6.1) µm; Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.8 (2); N = 30; Me = 8.7 × 5.4 µm; Qe = 1.6

results.notes:
This was found on a pine stump in a red/white pine planting.
The first three photos, taken over two weeks, illustrate the minimal growth of the original and rapid growth of the second to also miniature size.
At this point contact was interrupted until November 8 (six weeks later) when I found the same pair. The original hadn’t grown and was molded, the second (at least) had evidently produced spores and while it had grown, was still quite small.
So apparently producing spores as a stunted miniature. The summer was quite dry, especially early on, so this is likely a result of drought.
